advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>1982 - Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Stop in a store near you. Take a look. You'll be instantly taken with some of the features that make the IBM Personal Computer so different...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first 1982 U.S. Advert.<br><br> Advert said <br><br>THE COMMODORE 64 COULD BE THE MICROCOMPUTER INDUSTRY'S OUTSTANDING NEW PRODUCT INTRODUCTION SINCE THE BIRTH OF THIS INDUSTRY. (Shearson / American Express) <br><br><font color="#666666"> The value of a computer is determined by what it can do. What it can do is largely determined by its memory.<br> The Commodore 64's basic RAM is 64K. This amount of power is unusual in a micro at any price.<br> At $595 it is astonishing.<br> Compared with an Apple II+, for instance, the Commodore 64 offers 33% more power and considerably les than 50% of the cost.<br> Compared with anything else, it's even more impressive...<br><br> If you've been waiting for the "computer revolution", consider it as having arrived... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Our word processing system changed Isaac Asimov's mind about writing...<br> <b>"I may never use a typewriter again!"</b> Isaac likes the time he saves using SuperSCRIPSIT, our newest word processing program...<font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DIAGRAMS</strong></font><br><blockquote>PMI-80 diagram located in the case cover.<br> If you are interested in more diagrams of the PMI-80, dowload this zipped <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/Museum/downloads/Tesla_PMI80_Diagrams.zip">file</a> holding three diagrams of the whole system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT SEPT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> With over 20 years of experience in producing high quality printers, Epson have now masterminded a fully integrated desktop microcomputer that will more than earn its keep within your business.<br> The QX-IO is capable of performing all the tasks you will ever require of it, quickly and efficiently. Installation of the QX-IO can be carried out with the minimum of interruption, and with its easily understandable keyboard, it is simplicity itself to operate. Having such a diverse range of software packages available such as database from Pearl and office productivity and accountancy from Peachtree with CP/M and multifont BASIC as standard, the QX-IO can supply all the answers whatever your business.<br> Just look at what's on offer: a big memory - 192k upgradable to 256k RAM and all the graphics you'll ever need - and high resolution graphics at that.<br> The ability to communicate easily with other machines, including our own HX-20 and the advantage of using our fine range of printers, make the QX-lO a totally versatile system at a price you'll find impossible to equal.<br> £1735 plus VAT.<br> If you're looking at micros, look at the QX-IO. The system with all the answers. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Sorry, you don't play with me"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Micromachine 4000 but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted for reference...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV.1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"don't touch my Amstrad gaming system !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1989</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special 520-STFM bundle advert.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There's no catch. We're giving you the Atari 520 STFM and £500 worth of great software titles for just £399.99.<br> The twenty-three super titles include some of the greatest games and three excellent programs which introduce you to the BASIC programming language, computer-created music and the more popular computer applications such as word processing and spreadsheets...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HP-150 was widely used in industry by engineers and scientists.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1987<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...This elegant little machine takes family computing into new dimensions of creativity, excitement and productivity. It outruns and outguns office PCs as a business multi-tasker, performing a deskful of different jobs simultaneously at over 7 million steps per second in realtime... </font> </blockquote>

computer.colors: 16 (8 colours in mormal or bright modes)
computer.description:
In 1985, despite of the severe limitations of the political system, the Romanian computer company ICE-Felix, located in Bucharest, started to design and produce Sinclair Spectrum compatible computers.
The company was founded in 1970 and became the main computer equipments manufacturer in Romania. Several mini and microcomputers were developed, based initially on the French C.I.I. company licence.
The HC-85 was the first manufactured model. It was primarily intended for the Romanian schools and universities. As the engineers could not use the Spectrum / Feranti gate-array chip, they replaced it by a whole of logical chips that carried out exactly the same tasks.
The plastic case and the keyboard were of poor manufacture quality. However, the machine looked solid and the motherboard printed circuit was same quality level as the Western productions of the time.
computer.name: HC-85
computer.ports: Tape recorder, Joystick x 2, RGB, TV aerial, AC adaptor
computer.power: External AC adaptor. Built-in power regulation

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> EARLY MODEL #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture was found by <b>Grecu Cristi</b> in a Romanian math book released in 1989. It was probably the very first case version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> EARLY MODEL #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The case is different from the more common HC-85. But are they internal differences?<p class="petitgris">Thanks to the <a href="http://pocket.free.fr/" target="_blank">Pocket Computer Museum</a> for this picture.<br>This model is Arthur's property.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPLETE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Photo taken from first HC-85 brochure.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Zeno Mateescu</b> from Romania </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Even if the key were not very well aligned, the quality of the keyboard was better than that of the Spectrum.<br> The keys arrangement and the functions of each key was exactly the same as those of the Spectrum but in only one colour, which was not very convenient.<br> Note the reset switch located beside the 'Zero' key. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>All the active components (chips) mounted on this board seem to have been manufactured in Eastern Europe. <br><br> <b>(1)</b> Tape recorder audio signal filter area<br> <b>(2)</b> 32 KB RAM memory area<br> <b>(3)</b> 16 KB RAM memory area<br> <b>(4)</b> Video signals management area<br> <b>(5)</b> TV-UHF modulator<br> <b>(6)</b> Video RGB connector<br> <b>(7)</b> 2 x joystick connectors<br> <b>(8)</b> 16-pin keyboard connector<br> <b>(9)</b> Z80-A processor<br> <b>(10)</b> Expansion / Bus connector<br> <b>(11)</b> 16 KB ROM area<br> <b>(12)</b> Power connector<br> <b>(13)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>Inside the TV-UHF modulator.<br> RGB and joysticks connectors.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Tape recorder DIN plug<br> <b>(2)</b> Expansion / bus connector<br> <b>(3)</b> 2 x joystick DB-9 connectors<br> <b>(4)</b> RGB video output DB-15 connector<br> <b>(5)</b> TV-aerial output plug </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> WARRANTY SEAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>This small cup filled with pink wax covers one of the six screws used to close the case.<br> If the cup is empty, the warranty is void!</blockquote>
